text.headline: U.S. authorizes sanctions on Russia.
Rise in Russian cyberattacks.
Trump announces candidacy for president.
FBI begins Clinton email investigation.
Trump clinches the GOP nomination for president.
DNC announces it was hacked.
Comey closes Clinton email investigation.
Trump campaign helps change GOP platform on Ukraine/Russia.
Trump chooses Pence as VP.
Wikileaks releases 20,000 DNC emails.
DNC chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz resigns.
FBI begins investigation of DNC hack.
Manafort leaves Trump's campaign.
President Obama tells Putin to stop hacking.
Access Hollywood tape revealed.
Second presidential debate brings up hacking.
White House red phones another warning to Russia.
Trump fires Comey.
Putin denies role in U.S. elections.
NYT first reports Donald Trump Jr. 2016 meeting with Russian lawyer.
Donald Trump Jr. releases emails about meeting with Russian lawyer after offer of anti-Hillary Clinton material.
U.S. Senate sends new Russia sanctions to Trump's desk.
Russia reacts to sanctions bill, expelling U.S. diplomats.
Trump signs new sanctions against Russia, but says bill is "flawed."
Putin elected to six more years in office.
New U.S. sanctions against Russian oligarchs.
FBI begins investigating Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server while Secretary of State.
Intel director tells of attempted cyberattacks on presidential campaigns.
DNC's cybersecurity firm reports that Russians hacked the party's system.
Comey closes Clinton email investigation.
FBI begins investigation of DNC hack.
FBI receives letter from Page defending his communications.
DHS, DNI confirm Russian hacking of DNC.
Comey reopens Clinton investigation.
Comey again closes Clinton investigation.
Congressional Republican leaders announce they will investigate Russian attempts to disrupt the election.
Sen. Intell. Committee launches its Russia investigation.
Sens. Warren, Cardin ask Treasury to investigate Scaramucci-Russia Fund interaction.
Flynn questioned by the FBI.
Acting AG Sally Yates hears about Flynn interview.
Yates warns White House counsel Don McGahn about Flynn.
Treasury Sec. Mnuchin does not say if Scaramucci violated sanctions policy.
The FBI interviews Papadopoulos a second time.
House Intelligence Committee launches Russia investigation.
Comey pubicly verifies FBI investigation of Russia and Trump campaign connections.
Nunes visits White House grounds, learns about incidental surveillance of Trump associates.
Nunes personally briefs president on surveillance news.
Nunes cancels House intelligence hearing with Yates and former intelligence heads.
Trump fires Comey.
Washington Post reports Mueller is investigating Trump for possible obstruction of justice.
CNN: Near this date, intelligence chiefs told senators that the president asked them to deny any colllusion with Russia.
Trump attorney Jay Sekulow says he has not been told the president is under investigation for obstruction.
Following Mueller request, White House directs staff to preserve documents.
Report: Mueller expands investigation to include Trump business dealings.
Manafort meets with Senate Intelligence Committee staff, who ask about June 2016 Trump Tower meeting.
FBI agents raid Manafort's home.
Investor Bill Browder to senators: Veselnitskaya was pushing Moscow's agenda at 2016 Trump Tower meeting.
Trump campaign turns over 20,000 pages of documents to Senate Judiciary Committee.
Donald Trump Jr. turns over 250 pages of documents to Senate Judiciary Committee.
As Trump's attorney, Cohen sends letter to Congressional investigators disputing the Steele "dossier."
Senate Judiciary Committee daylong hearing with Fusion GPS founder.
NYT report details Russian fake accounts, bots on Twitter and Facebook.
U.S. bans government use of security software by firm connected to Russians.
Facebook gives Mueller information on Russian ads.
DHS identifies 21 state election systems targeted by Russian hackers.
Roger Stone closed-door testimony on Capitol Hill. Refuses to name who worked with him and Assange.
Papadopoulos signs plea agreement, guilty of lying to FBI and agreeing to cooperate.
Report: Mueller investigation includes Tony Podesta, brother of Clinton campaign Chairman John Podesta, for work connected to Manafort. (NYT)
WaPo publishes report that Clinton campaign paid Fusion GPS for anti-Trump research, including Steele dossier.
Mueller investigation indicts Manafort and his lieutenant Rick Gates on charges related to their past work for Ukrainian politicians.
Twitter, Google and Facebook representatives testify before Congress on Russian meddling.
Sessions testifies he now recalls the 2016 Papadopolous meeting.
Senate Judiciary Committee: Kushner didn't tell us about Wikileaks emails and talks for a "backdoor" channel with Russians.
Mueller's team and the president's attorneys discuss the possibility of him testifying, according to letter obtained by NYT.
Erik Prince testifies before House Intelligence Committee.
Mueller's team and the president's attorneys again discuss the possibility of him testifying, according to letter obtained by NYT.
White House outlines its cooperation with Mueller, points to 20+ interviews by Trump staffers.

Trump attorney John Dowd drafts letter to Mueller arguing that the president has the power to shut down investigations and that, because of such powers, his actions could never be obstruction of justice.
House Intelligence Republicans release once-classified memo accusing FBI of bias.
Mueller's team brings a second indictment, with 32 counts of tax and bank fraud, against Paul Manafort and Rick Gates.
Gates pleads guilty to two lesser charges, becomes a cooperating witness.
House Intelligence Democrats release a counter-memo on the FBI.
DOJ inspector general launches investigation of FBI, DOJ and possible abuse of FISA/surveillance powers, including with the Carter Page wiretaps.
Sen. Intelligence Committee interviews Felix Sater, who worked on Russia deals with Trump.
House Intelligence Committee releases separate final reports from GOP and Dems. Republicans conclude no evidence of collusion.
Senate Intelligence Committee: Russia tried to interfere in 2016 election to help Donald Trump.
Reuters report: Manafort's ex-son-in-law Jeffrey Yohai agreed to a plea deal in real estate case, may have to cooperate with Mueller.
Mueller drops a new obstruction of justice indictment against Manafort and his associate Konstantin Kilimnik. They are the first charges against Kilimnik.
Russia is ousted from the G8 group of industrial nations, because of its move to annex Crimea.
CNN reports the State Deptartment suspects Russians are behind a continuing, nearly yearlong and "worst ever" hack.
U.S. cybersecurity expert says he is seeing dramatic rise in cyber aggression from Russia.
DOD secretary Ashton Carter reveals suspected Russian hack of Pentagon.
Russians launch cyberattack against the Pentagon's Joint Staff email system. Officials shut it down temporarily.

The @Ten_GOP twitter account is created. It's purported to be the Tennessee Republicans but is later reported to be Russian trolls. It pushes support of Michael Flynn, allegations of vote fraud and gets dozens of RT's from Trump campaign staffers.
Clinton campaign chair John Podesta opens a phishing email sent by Russian hackers.
Another Clinton staffer falls for phishing scam.
The "professor" tells Trump advisor Papadopoulos that Russians have "thousands" of Hillary Clinton emails.
DNC announces it was hacked.
Guccifer 2.0 claims DNC hack, leaks report on Trump.
Guccifer 2.0 leaks DNC hack documents about Clinton.
Wikileaks releases 20,000 DNC emails.
Hackers release cell phone numbers, personal information and other documents about Democratic members of Congress.
Russian hackers targeted U.S. voting software company, according to NSA.
Wikileaks posts Podesta emails from DNC hack.
Obama admin. warns Russia to stop hacking.
Hackers use stolen logins to send cyberattack emails to 122 local voting officials.
Wikileaks releases CIA documents.
Putin denies role in U.S. elections, suggests "patriotic hackers" outside government may be behind hack.
Russia denies using Facebook to try to influence the election.
Report: Russian trolling operation likely cost $2.3 million, reached 6 million people.
Trump says G7 summit nations "should let Russia come back in."
Trump sends letter to Putin inviting him to the Miss Universe pageant, according to the Washington Post.
Trump tells David Letterman: "I've done a lot of business with the Russians."
Trump holds Miss Universe (which he owns) in Moscow, meets Russian entrepreneurs.
Trump tweets that U.S. must be strategic with Russia.
Trump announces candidacy for president.
Trump and Flynn first meet, speak for 90 minutes.
Trump and Putin praise each other, saying in separate statements they want better relations.
Trump meets with his national security team, including Sessions and Papadopoulos. The latter says he could arrange a meeting with Putin.
Trump meets Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak.
Russian magnate Aras Agalarov delivers an "expensive painting" to Trump for his birthday.
Trump accuses DNC of being behind the hack of their system.
Trump writes effusive thank you note to Agalarov for the painting.
Trump fires campaign manager Corey Lewandowski, Manafort takes over.
Trump gives NYC speech focused on his criticism of Hillary Clinton. It's unclear if this is what he was signaling June 7.
Trump says he hopes Russia finds missing Clinton emails.
Trump: Crimea prefers Russia.
Trump to Russian TV: Russia interference "pretty unlikely."
Russia formally complains to U.N. about criticism of Trump, others.
Trump team says Page made "no contribution" to the campaign.
Washington Post uncovers lewd Trump comments on Access Hollywood tape.
Trump doubts U.S. intel on Russia.
Trump praises Comey for reopening Clinton email probe.
Trump, named Time's 2016 person of the year, tells the magazine, "I do not believe Russia interfered."
Putin sends Trump a letter asking to restore U.S.-Russia relationship.
In Senate intelligence hearing, Comey won't say if FBI is investigating Trump.
Trump calls Comey over to shake hands during a White House reception.
Trump fires Yates for ordering DOJ not to defend the president's travel ban.
NYT: Trump instructs top WH lawyer to stop Sessions from recusing himself in the Russia investigation.
On Twitter, Trump says Obama had his "wires tapped" during 2016 elections.
Comey asks DOJ to publicly deny Trump's wiretap charge.
On or near this date,Trump reportedly asks intelligence chiefs to deny coordination between Russia and his campaign.
Trump reportedly asks Director of National Intelligence Daniel Coats to get Comey to back off investigation into Flynn.
Comey says Trump called him at the FBI and,  describing the Russia investigation as a "cloud," asked Comey to publicly say the president was not under investigation.
Trump calls Comey a "phony," tweeting the FBI director "was the best thing that ever happened to Hillary Clinton."
Trump tweets that story about campaign collusion with Russia is a "total hoax."
Trump fires Comey.
Trump retains adviser Marc Kasowitz as his private attorney for Russia probe.
Trump tweets that obstruction of justice allegations are part of a "witch hunt."
WaPo, NYT: Near this date, Trump ordered that Mueller be fired, but relented after White House counsel Don McGahn threatened to quit.
New York Times reports Trump transition team orders former staff to keep all documents related to Russia or Ukraine.
Trump tweets that he is being investigated "for firing the FBI director by the man who told me to fire the FBI director."
Trump again tweets the investigation is a "witch hunt."
Spicer says he does not know if Trump believes the Russians tried to meddle in the election.
In a FOX News interview, the president implies he may not want Mueller in the job.
Trump admits he does not have Oval Office tapes of Comey conversation.
The president acknowledges "Russian meddling" in a tweet, accuses Obama of doing nothing.
NYT reports Trump signed off on his son's statement about meeting with Russian lawyer.
Trump attorney says POTUS not involved in drafting his son's statement about Russia meeting.
President Trump's attorney again denies POTUS had role in Trump Jr. statement.
Trump praises son for releasing Russia meeting emails.
To NYT, Trump criticizes Sessions for recusing himself from Russia investigation.
Trump tells Wall Street Journal he's "just looking at" firing Sessions.
White House says Trump did weigh in on son's statement to NYT.
Trump misses the Oct. 1 deadline to impose new, required sanctions against Russia.
Trump tweets that events in Manafort indictment occurred before he was in the campaign and that there was no collusion.
At an Asian summit,Trump says Putin again privately assured him "he didn't meddle."
Trump tells reporters he accepts U.S. intel over Putin on meddling, saying "I'm with our agencies."
Mueller's team and the president's attorneys discuss the possibility of him testifying, according to letter obtained by NYT.
Mueller's team and the president's attorneys again discuss the possibility of him testifying, according to letter obtained by NYT.

Trump attorney John Dowd drafts letter to Mueller arguing that the president has the power to shut down investigations and that, because of such powers, his actions could never be obstruction of justice.
Trump's personal lawyer, John Dowd, said he hopes Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein shuts down the Mueller investigation.
Trump congratulates Putin on re-election, despite staff warning "do not congratulate."
John Dowd, Trump's attorney for the Mueller investigation, resigns.
Trump halts plan for possible new economic sanctions on Russia.
Trump rails against DOJ, FBI and Mueller in FOX interview. Also confirms Cohen worked for him  but was a "tiny, tiny fraction" of his legal work.
White House announces lead Russia probe lawyer Ty Cobb is leaving, will be replaced by Emmet Flood.
Trump demands DOJ investigate whether DOJ or the FBI spied on his campaign for political purposes.
Trump tweets he wished he had picked someone other than Sessions as attorney general.
Trump tweets that he "never fired James Comey because of Russia."

The NYT publishes Jan. letter by Trump's attorney asserting obstruction of justice charges could not apply to the president. The letter also indicates Trump dictated the statement by his son, Donald Trump Jr., about the 2016 Trump Tower/Russian lawyer meeting.
Trump tweets that he has the right to pardon himself and that the appointment of Mueller is unconstitutional.
Trump says G7 summit nations "should let Russia come back in."
Cohen tells Page Six that Trump is considering presidential run, spent $1 million on research.
Christopher Steele writes in his dossier that a Kremlin insider told him "the importance of Trump lawyer Cohen in the ongoing secret liaison with the Kremlin," and that Cohen's role had grown.
Cohen tweets "I have never been to Prague in my life," refuting a charge from the Steele dossier that he met Russians there in 2016.
Cohen meets with Russian oligarch Viktor Vekselberg at inauguration, according to NYT.
A pro-Russia peace plan that would lift sanctions is hand-delivered to Flynn at the White House, according to the NYT. The White House later denied receiving the plan.
Trump atty Michael Cohen sends letter to Congressional investigators disputing the "dossier" made public in January.
The FBI raids Cohen's home, office and hotel room, seizing records. Reports indicate he is under investigation for campaign finance, bank fraud.
Cohen asserts his Fifth Amendment right not to testify in the Stephanie Clifford (aka Stormy Daniels) case.
Trump tells Fox News that Cohen handled a "tiny, tiny fraction" of his legal work.

According to the AP, as early as this date, Paul Manafort pitched a plan to Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska to consult for the Putin government. Manafort denies his work was pro-Russian. Deripaska sued for libel.
In Ukraine, Yanukovych abruptly breaks with EU and embraces billions in aid from Moscow, contrary to Manafort's advice.
Manafort sends written pitch to Trump to work on the campaign.
Manafort hired by Trump campaign.
Near this date, Manafort meets with former Ukraine associate and Russian Army veteran Konstantin Kilimnik.
Manafort becomes campaign chairman.

As result of June 3 email, Russian lawyer meets at Trump Tower with Donald Trump. Jr, Kushner, Manafort and other Russians. Trump Jr. says the lawyer gave no information on Clinton or anything campaign-related
Manafort takes over running Trump's campaign.
Manafort writes in an email that he is willing to brief a VIP believed to be Russian oligarch Oleg Deripaska, according to WaPo. It's unclear if the briefings happened.
Manafort strongly denies taking any "off-books" cash for work in Ukraine.
Manafort resigns as Trump's campaign chair.
Christopher Steele writes in his dossier that a Kremlin insider told him Manafort had led efforts for a secret Trump-campaign relationship with Russians, until his ouster.
Manafort tells CBS News that the Ukrainian government concluded the "Black Ledger" was falsified.
Manafort's son-in-law's real estate company declares bankruptcy, documents millions owed to Manafort.
Spicer says Manafort had a "very limited role" in the campaign. Politifact later rates that statement as false.

Ukrainian journalist and Manafort critic releases 2009 receipt showing payment to Manafort for computer equipment. The critic says it is a cover for laundering. Manafort allies say it is a fake document.
Report: NY attorney general and Manhattan's district attorney have opened investigations into Manafort real estate transactions.
NYT: Around this date, Putin ally and ex-Manafort associate Oleg Deripaska asks for immunity deal with Congres, but no deal is made.
Manafort associate Konstantin Kilimnik tells Washington Post he has no relation to Russian intelligence. Others insist he *was* connected.
Manafort registers retroactively as a foreign agent for his previous work in Urkaine.
NYT reports Manafort owed millions to pro-Russia interests. Manafort spokesman says those debts are not current.
Manafort answers questions from Senate Intelligence Committee staff about 2016 meeting with Russian lawyer.
The FBI raids Manafort's home in Virginia.
Manafort turns over about 400 pages of documents to Senate Judiciary Committee.
NBC News reports Mueller is now investigating Tony Podesta, brother of Clinton campaign Chairman John Podesta, for previous work regarding Ukraine that was connected to Manafort.
Manafort and his deputy, Rick Gates, are charged with a combined 12 counts of financial and foreign agent crimes.  They both plead not guilty. Manafort spokesman issues a sharp statement.
Mueller's team brings a second indictment, with 32 counts of tax and bank fraud, against Paul Manafort and Rick Gates.
Gates pleads guilty to two lesser charges, becomes a cooperating witness in the Mueller investigation.
Reuters reports that Manafort's ex-son-in-law Jeffrey Yohai agreed to a plea deal in a real estate case and may have to cooperate in Mueller probe.
Prosecutors with Mueller's team filed court documents accusing Manafort of trying to tamper with witnesses in his case.
Mueller drops a new obstruction of justice indictment against Manafort and his associate Konstantin Kilimnik. They are the first charges against Kilimnik.

As result of June 3 email, Russian lawyer meets at Trump Tower with Donald Trump. Jr, Kushner, Manafort and other Russians. Trump Jr. says the lawyer gave no information on Clinton or anything campaign-related
Kushner submits a third security clearance form, amending it to include June 2016 meeting.
Kushner releases statement about Russia meetings, asserts his innocence and meets privately with Senate committee staff.
Kushner speaks privately with House Intelligence committee.
Senate Judiciary Committee charges that Kushner did not disclose talks for a "backdoor" channel with Russians and emails about Wikileaks.
In email chain, Donald Trump Jr. agrees to meet with Russian officials, says "I love it" to their offer to damage Hillary Clinton.

As result of June 3 email, Russian lawyer meets at Trump Tower with Donald Trump. Jr, Kushner, Manafort and other Russians. Trump Jr. says the lawyer gave no information on Clinton or anything campaign-related
Donald Trump Jr. disputes Democratic claims about Russian hacking.
Donald Trump Jr.reponds to a direct Twitter message from Wikileaks -- his first of three.
Donald Trump Jr. retweets a voter fraud allegation from the @Ten_GOP account later blocked by Twitter and reportedly run by Russian trolls.
Donald Trump Jr. releases statement about meeting with Russian lawyer.
Donald Trump Jr. releases emails about meeting with Russian lawyer after offer of anti-Hillary Clinton material.
Over this weekend, incoming White House Chief of Staff John Kelly reportedly tells Sessions his job is safe.
Reps. Mark Meadows and Jim Jordan write in an op-ed that it's time for Sessions to go.

The NYT publishes Jan. letter by Trump's attorney asserting obstruction of justice charges could not apply to the president. The letter also indicates Trump dictated the statement by his son, Donald Trump Jr., about the 2016 Trump Tower/Russian lawyer meeting.
Trump and Flynn first meet, speak for 90 minutes.
Flynn receives a $11,250 payment from a Russian freight company. Reason for the pay is unknown.
Flynn and his son meet with Russian ambassador Kislyak, seemingly at Flynn's request.
Flynn is a Trump adviser.
Flynn signs $600,000 contract to lobby for firm tied to Turkish government.
Flynn texts "Merry Christmas" to Kislyak.
Flynn questioned by the FBI.
White House learns Flynn misled Pence about his conversations with the Russians.
Yates invites McGahn to DOJ to review Flynn files; it's unclear whether he came.
A pro-Russia peace plan that would lift sanctions is hand-delivered to Flynn at the White House, according to the NYT. The White House later denied receiving the plan.
Flynn files financial disclosure form without citing Russian payments for speeches.
Reports: Flynn offered to testify to FBI, House, Senate in exchange for immunity. None took him up on the offer.
In Russian TV interview, Kislyak insists he and Flynn never talked about sanctions, though reports indicated otherwise.
Flynn pleads guilty to lying to the FBI, indicating he will cooperate with Mueller.
According to Papadopolous, a Trump "campaign supervisor," later identified as Sam Clovis, told him the campaign had a foreign policy goal of U.S.-Russia relations. Clovis' lawyer disputed that.
In Italy, Papadopoulos meets "the professor," who claims to be close with Russian officials.
Trump says Papadopoulos is on his campaign team.
In London, the "professor" introduces Papadopoulos to a "native Russian female" contact, supposedly a Putin relative. Papadopolous emails his campaign supervisor, who responds "great work."
Trump meets with his natl security team, including Sessions and Papadopolous. The latter says he could arrange a meeting w/ Putin.
Papadopoulos and his female Russian contact exchange emails about setting up a potential Russia trip.
The "professor" introduces Papadopoulos to a person said to be connected to the Russian foreign ministry.
Papadopoulos and his foreign ministry contact exchange more emails.
Papadopoulos emails a senior campaign advisor indicating the Russians are ready to meet with Trump.
The "professor" tells Papadopoulos that Russians have "thousands" of Hillary Clinton emails.
Papadopoulos emails a senior campaign advisor that he has some interesting messages from Moscow.
Russian foreign ministry contact emails Papadopoulos about a possible meeting in Moscow.
The "professor" emails Papadopoulos, who then emails a high-ranking campaign official that Russia would like to host Trump.
Papadopoulos emails another high-ranking campaign official about the idea of a Trump meeting with Russia.
Papadopoulos emails a high-ranking campaign official and then his campaign supervisor about a Trump meeting with Russian officials.
Papadopoulos writes the high-ranking campaign official that Russians would meet with him, off record, instead of Trump, if Trump is not an option.
Papadopoulos' campaign supervisor writes to encourage him to attend an off-record trip to Russia, "if feasible."
The FBI interviews Papadopoulos a second time.
Papadopolous deactives a Facebook account that contained some information about his contact with the "professor." His new account does not contain that information.
Papadopoulos is arrested upon arrival at Dulles Airport outside of Washington.
Papadopoulos signs plea agreement, stating he lied to the FBI in past interviews and indicating he is a cooperating witness.
Mueller unseals Papadopoulos' Oct. 5 plea agreement, detailing Russia and campaign contacts.
Trump says Carter Page is on his campaign team.
Page gives a lecture in Moscow.
Around this time, an FBI informant meets Page at a conference.
Trump campaign: Page is informal adviser.
Trump team denies Page's role in campaign.
Page writes to FBI, saying he didn't meet with any "sanctioned" Russians.
Page denies meeting Russians, takes leave from campaign.
Page travels to Moscow.
Page tells PBS NewsHour he had no Russian meetings in the last year.
In reversal, Page says he did meet with Russians.
Page testifies behind closed doors before House Intelligence Committee, which later releases a transcript.
DOJ inspector general launches investigation of FBI, DOJ and possible abuse of FISA/surveillance powers, including with the Carter Page wiretaps.
Stone leaves Trump campaign.
Jeff Sessions, then a senator, appears at Trump rally wearing a 'Make America Great Again' hat.
Sessions formally endorses Trump.
Sessions becomes chairman of the Trump campaign's national security advisory team.
The Trump campaign says Sessions will also lead Trump's foreign policy advisory team.
Sessions may have met with Kislyak.
Trump campaign signs contract with Cambridge Analytica, according to the Wall Street Journal.
DNC Chair Debbie Wasserman-Schultz resigns.
Roger Stone writes that Guccifer 2.0, not Russia, is responsible for hack.
Stone says he has communicated with Wikileaks' Julian Assange.
Stone tweets Podesta's "time" is coming.
Sessions meets with Kislyak.
Stone tweets "Wednesday @HillaryClinton is done. #Wikileaks."
Stone indicates more coming from Wikileaks.
Assange promises new Wikileaks info every week.
Podesta emails released by Wikileaks.
Podesta: Trump campaign is connected to hackers.
Stone: I have back channel to Assange.
Pence: The Trump campaign is not in cahoots with Wikipedia.
Bloomberg report details Trump's digital strategy, including near total reliance on Facebook ads and data.
Trump campaign manager Kellyanne Conway retweets @Ten_GOP account later blocked by Twitter and reportedly run by Russian trolls.

Buzzfeed publishes dossier from former British intelligence officer, with lengthy and some salacious allegations of how Russians tried to compromise Trump and his campaign. Trump tweets it is "fake news."
Trump transition aide Anthony Scaramucci, hedge fund CEO, meets with Kirill Dmitriev of the Russian Direct Investment Fund in Davos. Length of meeting unclear. RDIF was under sanctions at time.

Russian tycoon and Putin ally Viktor Vekselberg attends Trump's inauguration, according to WaPo. The NYT reported he was the guest of his cousin and RNC donor Andrew Intrater and met with Michael Cohen.
Sessions comes under fire for not disclosing two meetings with Kislyak.
Sessions recuses himself from any Russia investigations.
Stone posts tweet about "perfectly legal back channel" with Assange, then deletes it.
Sessions writes letter clarifying Senate testimony about contact with Russians.
Sens. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and Al Franken, D-Minn., ask Comey to investigate whether Sessions perjured himself.
Sessions tells 'Today' show he is also recusing himself from any investigation of Flynn.
Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein drafts a memo making a case for firing Comey, but only after he has been told that Comey is to be fired. It is not clear who directed him to write the memo.
Trump confidant Christopher Ruddy, CEO of Newsmax Media, tells NewsHour he thinks the president is "considering perhaps terminating" Mueller.
Sessions testifies before Senate Intelligence Committee, insists he did nothing improper and declines to answer questions about conversations with President Trump.
Pence hires a private attorney to represent him in the Russia investigation.
Trump's personal attorney, Michael Cohen, hires his own attorney to represent him in Russia probe.
Russian Ambassador Kislyak is recalled to Moscow.
To NYT, Trump criticizes Sessions for recusing himself from Russia investigation.
Sessions says he will serve "as long as appropriate."
Anthony Scaramucci announced as new White House communications director.
Trump tells Wall Street Journal he's "just looking at" firing Sessions.
Russia's RT news runs story in which Veselnitskaya insists Broward lied to Senate and he is behind a smear campaign.
Over this weekend, incoming White House Chief of Staff John Kelly reportedly tells Sessions his job is safe.
Scaramucci fired as White House communications director.
Sessions testifies before Senate, again insists he never colluded with Russians.
Sessions tells House committee he now recalls the March 2016 meeting in which Papadopolous relayed he was in contact with Russians. Sessions says he does not recall exactly what Papadopolous said.
FBI deputy director Andrew McCabe is fired, officially due to actions connected to the Clinton investigation. McCabe asserted he was fired because of the Russia investigation.
U.S. newly sanctions seven Russian oligarchs including Oleg Deripaska, who formerly worked with Manafort, and Viktor Vekselberg, who was at Trump's inauguration.
Senate Leader Mitch McConnell says he will not allow a floor vote on a bill to protect special counsel Mueller.
Trump tweets he wished he had picked someone other than Sessions as attorney general.
Trump tweets about Sessions again, blaming him for the continuing Russia investigation. "I would have quickly picked someone else," Trump says.
